Package org.jtrim2.stream

Interface ElementMapper<T,R>

Type Parameters:
T - the type of the elements of the input stream
R - the type of the elements this mapper is producing
public interface ElementMapper<T,R>
Defines an action mapping a single element of a stream to zero or more elements. Note that mapping to zero elements is effectively a filtering operation, so there is no special filtering operation. The simplest way to create a filtering mapper is by calling the filteringMapper method.

This interface can often be implemented as a lambda. For example: 


 ElementMapper<Integer, String> mapper = (element, consumer) -> {
   consumer.processElement("a." + element);
   consumer.processElement("b." + element);
 };
The above example maps each element of the input stream to exactly two other elements.

Note that although usually a mapper is side-effect free, this interface does not impose such restriction on its implementations. That is, users of this interface can't assume that they can call the mapper on the same element multiple times.

Thread safety

The thread-safety property of this interface are completely implementation dependent.

Synchronization transparency

Implementations of this interface are not required to be synchronization transparent.
See Also:
  • SeqMapper
  • SeqGroupMapper

  • Method Details

    • identity

      static <T> ElementMapper<T,T> identity()
      Returns a mapper mapping the input element to the same element as the input. This is a one-to-one mapping.
      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of the input element, which is also the type of the output
      Returns:
      a mapper mapping the input element to the same element as the input. This method never returns null.

    • flatteningMapper

      static <T, C extends Iterable<? extends T>> ElementMapper<C,T> flatteningMapper()
      Returns a mapper mapping an Iterable to as many elements as many the mapped Iterable has, and calling the consumer with each element separately in iteration order.
      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of the elements of the input Iterable, which is also the same as the output type
      C - the type of the Iterable (e.g., List)
      Returns:
      a mapper mapping an Iterable to as many elements as many the mapped. This method never returns null.

    • filteringMapper

      static <T> ElementMapper<T,T> filteringMapper(Predicate<? super T> filter)
      Returns a mapper mapping input elements to themselves if the given condition is true, and to nothing, if it is false.

      If the provided filter is side-effect free, then the returned mapper is also side-effect free.

      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of the input element, which is also the type of the output
      Parameters:
      filter - the filter to test if the element should be kept or not. If this filter returns false, then the element is removed, otherwise it is kept. This argument cannot be null.
      Returns:
      a mapper mapping input elements to themselves according to the given filter. This method never returns null.

    • oneToOneMapper

      static <T, R> ElementMapper<T,R> oneToOneMapper(Function<? super T,? extends R> mapper)
      Returns a simple mapper mapping each element of the input stream to exactly one other element.

      If the provided mapper action is side-effect free, then the returned mapper is also side-effect free.

      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of the input element
      R - the type of the elements this mapper is producing
      Parameters:
      mapper - the function mapping the elements of the input stream. Note that streams are not allowed to contain null values, so this function does not need to handle null elements, and may not return null. Also, this argument cannot be null.
      Returns:
      a simple mapper mapping each element of the input stream to exactly one other element according to the given function. This method never returns null.

    • map

      void map(T element, ElementConsumer<? super R> consumer) throws Exception
      Maps the given element to zero or more elements by passing them to the given consumer. The given consumer might be called any number of times (including zero). However, this method must assume that the provided consumer is no longer usable once this method returns. That is, passing the new elements to the consumer must happen synchronously with this method call.

      Exceptions thrown by the provided consumer must be propagated to the caller, and must not be wrapped (with the exception of checked exceptions not implementing Exception).

      Parameters:
      element - the element to be mapped. This argument cannot be null.
      consumer - the consumer to which the mapped elements are to be passed.
      Throws:
      OperationCanceledException - thrown if cancellation of the stream processing was detected by this method call. Note that although this method does not accept a CancellationToken for the sake of simplicity, the context usually has one.
      Exception - thrown if there was a processing failure. This usually means that the whole processing of the stream is to be discontinued.
